text_description: KZRH announces that radio sets must be registered with the Customs office. Defiance of the order is punishable by torture or death.

In the absence of prewar commercial radio and film, talents join stage shows directed by notable film directors including Lamberto Avellana, Gerardo de Leon, and Manuel Conde. Stage shows are bodabil with a play at the end.
The Japanese find radio equipment in the Jai-Alai building and put KZRH back on the air.

media_caption: American and Filipino troops surrendering at Bataan, 9 Apr 1942
media_credit: Photo from United States National Parks Service
text_description: On Voice of Freedom, Norman Reyes reads the historic announcement “Bataan Has Fallen,” written by Salvador P Lopez, and translated and read in Tagalog by Francisco Isidoro. Photo: American and Filipino troops surrendering at Bataan, 9 Apr 1942 (United States National Parks Service)

article_title: 1942 Broadcast Voice of Juan de la Cruz
text_description: Voice of Freedom ceases broadcast. Voice of Juan de la Cruz goes on the air. KZRC ceases broadcast.

media_caption: Japanese propaganda letters
media_credit: Photo from U.S. Army Center of Military History
text_description: The Japanese propaganda corps, the Hodobu, strictly monitors and controls radio, stage shows, printed media, and film. Photo: Japanese propaganda letters (U.S. Army Center of Military History)
Voice of Juan de la Cruz ceases broadcast with the capture of its broadcasters.

media_caption: “Reconditioning” or reconfiguration of radio sets, ca 1943
media_credit: Photo from US National Archives and Records Administration
text_description: Jan 6: The Japanese order the “reconditioning” of shortwave radio receivers to receive only authorized broadcasts. (Photo from US National Archives and Records Administration)
The Philippine Symphony Orchestra is formed and performs classical music over KZRH.
Declaring “independence” for the Philippines, the Japanese change the call letters of KZRH to PIAM.
Upon Gen Douglas MacArthur’s landing, Voice of Freedom operates under the call letters WVLC from Leyte.
The Japanese re-constitute the Board of Review for Moving Pictures (BRMP).
PIAM ceases broadcast.
Several mobile army stations are sent to Japan while the remaining stations are integrated into KZFM in Manila.
KZPI goes on test broadcast under the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation.
The US government turns over KZFM to the Philippine government, under the office of Vice Pres. and Foreign Affairs Secretary Elpidio Quirino.

media_caption: Chronicle Broadcasting Network Building, Aduana Street, Intramuros, Manila, 1955
text_description: Eugenio Lopez Sr acquires the news daily The Manila Chronicle. It will later lend its name to the first Lopez broadcast company, the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). (Photo from ABS-CBN)
The Department of Commerce and Industry takes jurisdiction over the Radio Control Division (RCD).
Radio Corporation of the Philippines merges with Far Eastern Radio Inc.
Radio Corporation of America (RCA) buys Radio Corporation of the Philippines.

The Philippine Legislature enacts the Ship Radio Station Law, establishing the first radio regulatory office, the Radio Construction and Maintenance Section, under the Telegraph Division of the Bureau of Posts.
The Philippine Legislature creates the Board of Censorship for Moving Pictures (BCMP).

The Philippines requests the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) to replace its radio call letters from the American KZ to PI (Philippine Islands). The ITU instead grants the Philippines part of the D series, which until then was used exclusively by Germany.
KZRM carries American and other foreign programs.
The Philippine Legislature enacts the Radio Control Law, shifting regulation of radio broadcasting from the Bureau of Posts to the newly created Radio Control Board.
The Philippine Legislature passes a law to collect license fees from owners of radio sets.
Erlanger & Galinger opens KZEG, and features local opera and sarsuwela singers.

media_caption: Franklin D. Roosevelt's fireside chat on the US Supreme Court Reform Plan, 1937
media_credit: Photo from Harris & Ewing Collection, Library of Congress
text_description: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s “fireside chats” go on air, the first to use radio to address audiences directly. (Photo from Harris & Ewing Collection, Library of Congress)
Balagtasan on the Air begins airing on KZRM.

media_caption: Lina Flor, writer, host, and principal character of Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Library Collection
text_description: Si Aling Juanang Mapag-Impok, a soap-opera-cum advice program by Lina Flor (in photo), and Kuwentong Kutsero, a satire on Philippine society and politics produced by Horacio de la Costa, go on the air. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Library Collection)
The National Assembly changes Board of Censors for Motion Picture’s name to Board of Review for Moving Pictures and expands its coverage to locally produced films distributed abroad.

Erlanger & Galinger sells KZRM and KZEG to Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation of publisher J. Amado Araneta, marking the first cross-media ownership of radio and newspapers. He changes KZEG’s call letters to KZRF.
KZRM covers live the sarsuwela Walang Sugat by Severino Reyes at the Metropolitan Theater.
KZRC re-opens under Heacock.
Iyo Karpo, the advice-dispensing radio character of Ben Zubiri, hosts Pangutan-a Ako and Purico Amateur Hour on KZRC. Zubiri gains fame as the composer and singer of the Cebuano classic "Matud Nila."
The Commonwealth government opens KZND.

Before retreating to Corregidor, Gen Douglas MacArthur orders the destruction of radio equipment. Some KZRH equipment is brought to Corregidor while other pieces are hidden in the Jai-Alai building on Taft Avenue.
All commercial radio programming ceases as the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) blows up radio transmitters and destroys equipment.

media_caption: Lt Gen Jonathan Wainwright announcing the surrender of Corregidor on 7 May 1942 on Japanese-controlled KZRH
text_description: The Japanese order Maj Gen Jonathan Wainwright to announce on KZRH the surrender of the Philippine-American forces to the Japanese. (Photo from US National Archives and Records Administration)
Pres Manuel Roxas transfers KZFM to the newly created Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS) under the Office of the President.
KZRC re-opens in Cebu as an affiliate of Manila Broadcasting Company.

media_caption: Full size reproduction of the on air announcement for KZAS in 1948
text_description: KZAS, the first radio station in the Philippines with religious programming, goes on the air. (Photo from FEBC International Historical Archive)
A second Cebu station, KZBU, opens under Philippine Broadcasting Corporation.
Due to import restrictions on TV equipment, James Lindenberg focuses on radio and establishes DZBC
All Philippine stations adopt the initial call letter D.
DXMV goes on the air in Cotabato City, the first radio station with a franchise to operate in Mindanao.
Local recording companies produce records of Philippine music.
The University of Santo Tomas establishes the Catholic station DZST.
The first detective drama on radio, Tony Narra, airs on DZBB.
Robert “Bob” Stewart establishes DZBB under the Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc.
Congress grants James Lindenberg’s Bolinao Electronics Company a franchise to operate a radio and TV station.
DZBB goes on the air.
The Radio Control Division, by then under the Radio Control Board, is transferred to the Department of Public Works and Communications.

media_caption: RMN logo, 1952
media_credit: Photo from Michael Jord B. Abiera, CC-BY-SA
text_description: Aug 28: The Canoy brothers, Henry and Reuben, found the Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) with the first radio station in Cagayan de Oro City, DXCC. Photo: RMN logo, 1952 (Michael Jord B. Abiera, CC-BY-SA)

media_caption: Public invitation to DZAQ-TV telecasts, 1953
text_description: The first TV station in the Philippines, ABS’s DZAQ-TV Channel 3, goes on the air. Photo: Public invitation to DZAQ-TV telecasts, 1953 (Photo from Lou Gopal, Manila Nostalgia)
Records of Mambo Magsaysay, the campaign jingle of Presidential candidate Ramon Magsaysay, are distributed free and aired almost everywhere in town fiestas.
A TV adaptation of Cyrano de Bergerac directed by James Reuter is broadcast live on ABS Channel 3 as the first drama program aired on Philippine TV.

media_caption: Tawag ng Tanghalan hosts Lopito and Patsy
media_credit: Photo from James de la Rosa/Baul ni Juan
text_description: Tawag ng Tanghalan airs on DZBB. Photo: Tawag ng Tanghalan hosts Lopito and Patsy (James de la Rosa/Baul ni Juan)
Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc. expands and puts DZXX on the air.
ABS launches DZYL, the first radio station to broadcast via frequency modulation (FM).
Republic Act 1476 abolishes the Radio Control Board but retains Radio Control Division under the Department of Public Works and Communications.
CBN launches DZXL.
DZUP begins noncommercial shortwave radio broadcast at the University of the Philippines in Diliman.
CBN’s DZXL-TV Channel 9 begins broadcasting.
The Benedicto family, publisher of the newspaper Philippine Daily Express, establishes DZKB under Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS).
Similar to the balagtasan, Cancionan on the Air airs on DWDW in Pangasinan.
The Board of Review for Motion Pictures is renamed Board of Censors for Motion Pictures, with jurisdiction expanded to include movies aired on TV.

media_caption: Dance number from Dance Time with Chito, ca 1970
media_credit: Photo from GMA Gold: Fifty Years of Broadcast History, GMA Network Inc, 2001
text_description: Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc establishes DZBB-TV Channel 7 with its first program, the dance show Dance Time with Chito, hosted by Chito Feliciano. (Photo from GMA Gold: Fifty Years of Broadcast History, GMA Network Inc, 2001)
The Department of Public Works and Communications renames the Radio Control Division as Radio Control Office.

media_caption: Abelardo Yabut Sr, founder of NBC
text_description: Nation Broadcasting Corporation begins operations with DXYZ in Zamboanga and DZAM in Manila. Photo: Abelardo Yabut Sr, founder of NBC (TV5)
Mareco Broadcasting Network begins radio broadcasts and specializes in local music.
The Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc. is renamed Republic Broadcasting System.
The National Media Production Center is created under the Office of the President.
Republic Act 4379 establishes the Institute of Mass Communication in UP, the first to teach broadcasting in the Philippines. It will become the College of Mass Communication in 1988.
The National Media Production Center acquires the facilities of the Voice of America in Malolos, Bulacan and begins operating it as the Voice of the Philippines with the call letters DZRP.

media_caption: Print advertisement of Gorio and His Jeepney, ca 1966
text_description: The sitcom Gorio and His Jeepney airs on ABC 5. (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)
ABS Channel 3 airs the first color TV transmission in the Philippines.

media_caption: Print advertisement for Balintataw
text_description: Balintataw, a joint venture between the Philippine Educational Theater Association and ABC Channel 5, begins airing original TV adaptations of Philippine literary pieces. (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)

media_caption: ABS-CBN logo, 1967-1972
text_description: ABS and CBN stations officially merge as ABS-CBN. (Photo from ABS-CBN)
ABS-CBN Channel 3 produces Halalan ’67, a 36-hour live nationwide television coverage of the results of the 1967 Congressional elections.
DZFX airs and becomes the first successful FM station in the Philippines with high fidelity stereophonic sound.
DZEC goes on the air under the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation for the Iglesia ni Cristo.
ABS-CBN airs the coverage of the assassination of US Senator Robert Kennedy via the first satellite transmission on Philippine TV.
The Ateneo Center for Educational TV begins transmitting televised lessons to schools through closed circuit transmission and via a microwave link to IBC TV-13.
The drama anthology Panagimpan airs on ABS-CBN.
The sitcom Tisoy, based on a satirical comic strip by Nonoy Marcelo, airs on ABC 5.

media_caption: Scene from Sunday, Sweet Sunday, with Fides Cuyugan-Asensio in polka dots and Jimmy Melendrez to her right, 1969
text_description: The musical program Sunday Sweet Sunday, the first TV program in the country to broadcast in color, airs. (Photo from CCP)
DZST is transferred to the Philippine Radio Educational and Information Center Inc. Its call letters are changed to DZRV, for Radio Veritas.
RBS Channel 7 carries for Philippine television channels the satellite broadcast of the landing of the Apollo 11 spaceship on the moon.
Roberto Benedicto lists KBS in the Philippine Stock Exchange.
The long-running talk show for families of Overseas Filipino Workers, To Saudi with Love, airs on DZRH.

media_caption: Nora Daza in her younger years
text_description: CBN airs the first live cooking show on TV, Let’s Cook with Nora, hosted by Nora Daza (in photo), later renamed Cooking It Up with Nora, enjoying a 25-year run. (Photo from Nina Puyat)

media_caption: Athletes parade at the Olympic Stadium for the opening ceremony of the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, West Germany.
text_description: KBS Channel 9 airs the live coverage of the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, West Germany. (Photo from Romák Éva/Fortepan)

Pres Ferdinand Marcos moves Radio Control Office to the Board of Communications (BOC), the first quasi-judicial body with adjudicatory powers on matters involving telecommunication services. The BOC remains administratively under the Department of Public Works and Communications.
Channels 7 and 13 resume broadcast while Channels 2, 4, 5, and 11 remain off the air. Local TV programs, with new titles that reflect what Marcos calls the New Society, are allowed to go on air.
Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran, the first public affairs talk show to be simulcast live by all radio and TV stations in the country, airs.

Presidential Decree 36 cancels legislative franchises issued by Congress to radio and TV stations prior to the proclamation of martial law and requires all broadcast operations to obtain prior clearance from the newly-created Mass Media Council.
Roberto Benedicto inaugurates domestic satellite communications (DOMSAT) with RPN as the transmitting network of 11 satellite earth stations for all broadcasts from the Office of the President.

media_caption: Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas logo
media_credit: Photo from Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas
text_description: The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP), later Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas, is organized by leaders of the broadcast media industry. It is among the means the martial law government used to control the media. It will operate independently when Marcos rule ends.

media_caption: Original cast of John en Marsha, seated left to right, Maricel Soriano, Dolphy, Nida Blanca, Rolly Quizon, and standing behind, Matutina and Dely Atay-atayan, 1975
text_description: The sitcom John en Marsha begins its 17-year run on RPN 9. (Photo from ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation logo
text_description: Roberto Benedicto renames KBS Radio Philippines Network and continues broadcast on Channel 9; begins a takeover of almost all the radio and television stations and facilities of the Lopezes throughout the country; and establishes Barangay (later Banahaw) Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), which starts airing on Channel 2. (Photo from Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation)
BBC Balita, the first primetime TV news in Filipino after the declaration of martial law, airs.
The execution of convicted drug lord Lim Seng is broadcast on television.
The Mass Media Advisory Council replaces the Mass Media Council. It issues permits for the operation of mass media in the Philippines, subject to Marcos’s approval.

The 1973 Constitution takes effect, banning foreigners from owning mass media in RP. Marcos presidential aide Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Robert Stewart’s lawyer Felipe L Gozon, and his accountant Menardo R. Jimenez buy the controlling interest in RBS from Stewart, an American.
The drama anthology Obra Maestra airs on BBC 2.
Government Television Network is established, airs on Channel 4, with airtime shared by the Department of Public Information, the National Media Production Center, and Radio Philippines Network.
Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Felipe L. Gozon, and Menardo Jimenez rename RBS Greater Manila Area Radio-Television Arts (GMA-RTV), later shortened to GMA
The Radio Control Office is renamed Telecommunications Control Bureau..
The Mass Media Advisory Council is abolished and its powers are transferred to the Philippine Council for Print Media and the Broadcast Media Council.
Roberto Benedicto buys the controlling interest in IBC and renames it Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation while the Canoys buy RMN back from Andres Soriano Sr.
The Marcos government establishes DWIM-FM.
The Board of Censors for Motion Pictures is run mostly by military personnel until 1981.

media_caption: Voltes V and Purefoods Hotdog ad., 1978
text_description: The Japanese robot animation program Voltes V airs on GMA7. Marcos will ban it a year later. (Photo from Eduardo de Leon Collection)
Roberto Benedicto ventures into cable television through Sining Makulay Inc.

media_caption: Eat Bulaga! hosts Tito, Vic, and Joey, 2016
text_description: Blocktimer Television and Production Exponents (TAPE Inc.) launches Eat Bulaga! on RPN 9. Photo: Eat Bulaga! hosts Tito, Vic, and Joey, 2016 (Photo from TAPE, Inc)
The drama Marcelino Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro?, adapted from a Spanish novel, airs on BBC 2.
The drama anthology Rosas airs on GTV 4.
RPN 9 airs the first mini-series Malayo Pa ang Umaga, based on Stevan Javellana's novel, Without Seeing the Dawn.
Maskara, a drama anthology about the entertainment industry, airs on BBC 2.

media_caption: Seal of the National Telecommunications Commission of the Philippines, 2017
text_description: Pres Ferdinand Marcos creates the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications. The NTC integrates the functions of the Board of Communications and the Telecommunications Control Bureau.
RPN 9 airs a two-hour special on the animated version of the Iluko epic Biag ni Lam-ang.
The National Telecommunications Commission is empowered to oversee technical matters concerning the broadcast media.
GTV is re-named Maharlika Broadcasting System, with the National Media Production Center in full control of the station and its airtime.
GMA 7 airs Lovingly Yours Helen, a drama anthology based on letters sent by viewers.
The Board of Censors for Motion Pictures is re-organized and re-named Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television.
The Philippine Council for Print Media and the Broadcast Media Council are abolished. The power to grant broadcast franchises is given to the Batasang Pambansa.
Pres Ferdinand Marcos announces on This Week with David Brinkley on American ABC-TV that a presidential snap election will be held.

Juan Ponce Enrile asks DZRV to cover the announcement of his, and Fidel V. Ramos’s, break with Pres Ferdinand Marcos. Cardinal Sin calls people via DZRV to protect Enrile and Ramos. By nightfall a siege is underway. Initially, only DZRV covers the event live, but provincial and foreign stations carry its signals.

The DZRV transmitter is bombed presumably by Marcos partisans. Its broadcast moves to DZRJ on Santa Mesa, identifies itself as Radyo Bandido, and begins broadcast with "Mambo Magsaysay." Meanwhile, DZRH airs Marcos’s press conference where he declares he is in control of the situation.
The media cover the election campaign, the polling, the count, and the election aftermath.

media_caption: Tabulators manning the PICC plenary hall walk out in protest of cheating in favor of Marcos with Comelec's quick count computer terminals, 10 February 1986
text_description: The media cover the separate counts of the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) and the citizens’ group NAMFREL. TV and newspaper images of computer programmers walking out of the COMELEC count in protest strengthen public perception of a rigged tally in favor of Marcos. (Photo by Alex Baluyut, Malaya)

As Pres Ferdinand Marcos goes on air on MBS 4, he is interrupted by Gen Fabian Ver to ask permission to “annihilate” the rebels. The announcement is cut off by rebel troops who take over MBS 4 and, soon, other stations.

media_caption: Protesters pushing against government tanks with media men documenting the events at EDSA
media_credit: Photo by Pete Reyes, People Power: The Philippine Revolution of 1986, Presidential Museum and Library
text_description: The media, including international media, cover the events at EDSA. Live broadcast signals from Manila are carried by provincial stations. The whole nation and the rest of the world watch and listen. (Photo by Pete Reyes, People Power: The Philippine Revolution of 1986, Presidential Museum and Library)

media_caption: Logo of PTV-4 in 1995
text_description: MBS is renamed People’s Television Channel 4 (PTV 4).
Cory Aquino’s government returns ABS-CBN to the Lopezes and sequesters RPN 9 and IBC 13.

media_caption: Randy David, host of Public Forum, 1997
text_description: IBC 13 airs several firsts: Its documentary Ceasefire discusses a ceasefire between the military and the National Democratic Front-New People’s Army (NDF-NPA). Its public affairs program Truth Forum (later renamed Public Forum), hosted by Randy David (in photo), becomes the first to use Filipino as language of serious discussion. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: ABS-CBN's logo (1986-1999)
text_description: ABS-CBN resumes broadcast on Channel 2 (Photo from ABS-CBN)

Radio and TV cover the coup attempts live. In one of the attempts, DZRH reporter Rey Langit negotiates on the air with the rebels for a ceasefire to allow Department of Tourism Secretary Rafael Alunan to escort local and foreign tourists out of the battle zone in Makati.

media_caption: Star Cinema logo
text_description: ABS-CBN establishes Star Cinema as its filmmaking arm. Screenshot from Cesar Blanco/Youtube
Hamon sa Pamahalaan, Hamon sa Taumbayan, considered the first documentary to use the Filipino language, airs on IBC13.
The 1987 Philippine Constitution recognizes the vital role of communication and information in nation-building.
ABS-CBN 2 re-launches itself with the live musical special Star Network: Ang Pagbabalik ng mga Bituin.

media_caption: Official logo of DZUP
text_description: DZUP, off the air since the declaration of martial law, resumes broadcast under the management of the UP Institute of Mass Communication.

media_caption: The Probe Team hosts Howie Severino and Cheche Lazaro, 2009
text_description: Probe moves to GMA 7 and renames itself The Probe Team. Photo: The Probe Team hosts Howie Severino and Cheche Lazaro, 2009 (Ella Marie Evangelista-Martelino)
Hilda Drama Specials, a drama anthology airs, on RPN 9.
The CCP launches the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo.

Produced by the Ateneo Center for Social Policy and Public Affairs and the Foundation for Media Alternatives, the documentary Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan, airs on ABS-CBN. For its resolute anti-US bases stance, MTRCB Chair Manuel Morato bans the TV special.

media_caption: Tatak Pilipino hosts Gel Santos-Relos and Jim Paredes
text_description: The telemagazine Tatak Pilipino airs on ABS-CBN. Photo: Tatak Pilipino hosts Gel Santos-Relos and Jim Paredes

media_caption: Logo of SKYcable
text_description: ABS-CBN expands into cable TV distribution by establishing SKYcable.
ABC returns to the air with the call sign DWET-TV and operates the Dream FM Network.
Republic Act 7306 grants PTV 4 a charter.

media_caption: Logo of SBN 21 from 1996 to 2005
text_description: The first TV station to broadcast on the ultra-high frequency (UHF) band, Southern Broadcasting Network (SBN) Channel 21, goes on the air.
RMN launches DWKC-TV Channel 31 on UHF, the first to carry a movie format.
Rajah Broadcasting launches RJTV Channel 29 as an all-female and lifestyle station, the first to host home TV shopping.

media_caption: Cinema One logo, 2001
media_credit: Photo from Michael Jord B. Abiera, CC-BY-SA
text_description: ABS-CBN launches Cinema One, a pay TV channel targeted at Filipinos overseas, on SkyCable. (Photo from Michael Jord B. Abiera, CC-BY-SA)
The historical drama Bisperas ng Kasaysayan airs on RPN 9.

media_caption: The Filipino Channel logo, 1994-1996
text_description: ABS-CBN Global Limited's The Filipino Channel (TFC) is launched to cater to Filipinos worldwide. (Photo from Amiel Estoy Peña, CC-BY-SA)

media_caption: Star Records Logo, 1994-2000
text_description: ABS-CBN produces and distributes music by establishing Star Records.
GMA launches DWDB-TV Channel 27 on UHF, called CityNet TV from 1995 to 1999, Entertainment Music Channel (EMC) from 1999 to 2001, and back as CityNet in 2005, as GMA’s outlet for imported programs.
Tinig ng Nursia: Women's Studies on the Air, produced by St. Scholastica's College, airs on DWSS.
GMA Network establishes GMA Films.
The Mexican telenovela Marimar airs on RPN 9, shifting television’s late afternoon and evening primetime programming and ushering in the dubbing industry in the country.

media_caption:
Isip Pinoy

RPN transitional program bumper, 1986
text_description: The talk show Isip Pinoy airs on RPN 9. (©1986 Radio Philippines Network)
ABS-CBN launches Sarimanok News Network (SNN), now ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC), as the Philippines’ first 24/7 news channel on SkyCable.
ABS-CBN acquires Studio 23 on the UHF band.

media_caption: I-Witness logo from episode 'Kidneys for Sale,' a documentary by Jessica Soho
text_description: The documentary i-Witness airs on GMA. (Photo from GMA Public Affairs)

media_caption: Cheche Lazaro, with guest Sarah Geronimo, in Cheche Lazaro Presents, 2014
text_description: The magazine show Cheche Lazaro Presents airs on GMA 7, then moves to ABS-CBN in 2010. (Photo from Probe Productions, Inc)

media_caption: ABS-CBN Interactive, 1999
text_description: ABS-CBN launches ABS-CBN Interactive (ABS-CBNi, later ABS-CBN Digital Media) as its digital and internet subsidiary.
ABS-CBN launches the Lifestyle Network channel on SKYcable.
ABS-CBN launches the Knowledge Channel on SKYcable.

media_caption: Atty Mario Bautista with star witness Clarissa Ocampo during the trial of former Pres Joseph Estrada
media_credit: Screenshot from GMA News and Public Affairs
text_description: Filipinos witness through live radio and television coverage an elected president stand trial. (Screenshot from GMA News and Public Affairs)
DZRV's Pitlag! Kwento ng Buhay becomes the first Philippine radio program to win an international award in a NY Festival.
Pres Estrada's trial continues on live radio and television.
Jaime Cardinal Sin calls on the people via DZRV to once again rebel against a president, this time Joseph Estrada, following accusations of massive corruption.
PTV 4 is rebranded as National Broadcasting Network (NBN).
The children's magazine show Usapang Pambata airs on DXMD in Kidapawan and DXMS in Cotabato.
Greater Manila Area Radio-Television Arts (GMA) Channel 7 changes its name to Global Media Arts (GMA) Channel 7.
Both ABS-CBN and GMA send journalists to cover the US invasion of Iraq.
The Chinese telenovela Meteor Garden airs on ABS-CBN. Other chinovelas from Taiwan and koreanovelas from South Korea follow.

A group led by Antonio Cojuangco Jr, former chair of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) and owner of Dream Satellite Broadcasting, acquires ABC. He retains ownership of Dream FM Network, but later sells it to Ultrasonic Broadcasting System.

media_caption: GMA Pinoy TV Logo, 2005-2011
media_credit: Photo from Franz Anthony Copina, Russel Wiki
text_description: GMA launches its first international channel, GMA Pinoy TV. (Photo from Franz Anthony Copina, Russel Wiki)
GMA CityNet changes its name to Channel Q, a lifestyle channel for women.
The CCP produces the children’s radio show Wan Dey Isang Araw on DZAS.
The radio drama Pinoy Klasiks, based on Filipino literary classics, airs on DZAS.
ABS-CBN establishes Hero TV channel on SKYcable.

media_caption: Wowowee logo, 2005-2006
text_description: A stampede of mostly impoverished 30,000 fans at the entrance of the Philippine Sports Stadium on the anniversary of the television game show Wowowee kills 73 and injures 392. (Photo from Aries Andres)
ABS-CBN merges radio and television through DZMM Teleradyo on SKYCable.
ABC relaunches as TV5 under ABC Development Corporation.

media_caption: TV5 Logo, 2008
text_description: Antonio Cojuangco's group sells its share to PLDT’s broadcasting division, Media Quest Holdings Incorporated, owned by Manuel V Pangilinan. TV5 is rebranded as the Kapatid network while its radio station is branded as Radyo Singko.
Media Quest shifts FM programming from mainly music to news and talk, a format traditionally used in AM radio.
GMA News TV Channel 27 replaces QTV-11 and Channel Q.
The "macho dance" controversy involving a minor on the Willing Willie show on ABC 5 sparks outrage among activist groups and ordinary citizens.

media_caption: Seal of the National Telecommunications Commission of the Philippines, 2017
text_description: Pres Aquino puts the National Telecommunications Commission under the Office of the President.
NBN re-introduces its brand name People's Television or PTV4.

media_caption: MTRCB program classifications for movie and television/p>
text_description: The MTRCB adds the SPG (Striktong Patnubay at Gabay, or Strict Parental Guidance) classification to TV programs. (Photo from MTRCB)

media_caption: Cignal Digital TV logo, 2009-2013
text_description: TV5 partners with Cignal Digital TV for cable and satellite TV, including the channels Colours for lifestyle and reality shows, Hyper for sports and entertainment, and Bloomberg TV, a business news channel. TV 5 archives and airs programs on Fox Filipino.

media_caption: MTRCB, headed by its chair, Eugenio Villareal, center, imposing strict measures on Pinoy Big Brother to protect minor housemates, 2015
text_description: The MTRCB orders ABS-CBN to attend a mandatory conference on gender sensitivity following the condemnation by the Philippine Commission on Women of the June 4 episode of the reality show Pinoy Big Brother: All In, where program participants are instructed to participate in a nude painting activity. (Photo from MTRCB)
The Rich Man's Daughter, a telenovela on lesbian characters, airs on GMA7.
